ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: The course covers a lot of important and relevant material if you're interested in energy, but the problem sets were too time-consuming in relation to the amount of learning you get out of the process. The questions were often poorly-written and confusing, leading to quite a bit of wasted time trying to figure out what they were asking.

I am commenting on the class generally, and particularly on the pedagogy of the course. I was disappointed with this class. The lectures were only tangentially related to the problem sets. The problem sets were quantitative, but the lectures were mostly either qualitative discussions of consumer behavior or general discussions of graphs. The lectures did not teach students how to complete the problem sets. Moreover, the problem sets were often poorly worded. Even worse, many of the questions required students to go on extensive fishing expeditions looking for information and data sets. Finally the problem sets were computationally quite simple, but were made artificially convoluted by the need to incessantly convert from one set of units to another, then to another, then back again. These types of questions are not conceptually challenging, and do not encourage students to think creatively or analytically. They merely take up a lot of time.
See answers below.
Best class at FES I've taken so far, also the hardest
excellent course for anyone interested in Energy. This course requires hard work and curiosity
This course was an excellent introduction to Energy Systems. However, the lecture style often involved questioning students in a way that belittled students.

Questions 8,9,10: The instructor for this class was, in my opinion, very disrespectful towards his students. At every single class, he would make at least one derogatory comment about FES, its students, or just environmentalists in general (for example, environmentalists donât know anything/canât do anything right/have no idea how the real world works). And, he never made any negative comments about students from other schools (SOM, law school). It made me feel terrible about myself as well as my choice of school and I could not help but wonder why a professor would hate a school (FES) so much yet still work there. He was also very impatient with his students. When students asked him questions in class, he would oftentimes scoff at them as if he was in disbelief about how someone could ask such a stupid question. Only a small handful of students would participate in class because most students felt too intimated to make comments or ask questions. Granted, he told us on the very first day of class that his job is not to help inflate our egos, but at the same time, I think itâs important to not damage morale. At the beginning of the semester, he told one of my friends in the class that she went to the wrong school if she wanted to study energy. Considering what he says about FES, I believe that he genuinely thinks this is true. I understand that some students are more sensitive than others, and perhaps Iâm just not a fan of his teaching style, but I honestly felt like I was paying someone to make fun of me and my poor choice of a school/program.
The course is taught in a different manner than most other subjects at FES. Classes are mostly theoretical, and allow little student driven interaction/discussion.

ESA represented the work of my three other classes added together. It was by FAR the toughest in terms of workload, sometimes to its own detriment. For example, on weeks with heavy problem sets, there actually was not time to also complete the assigned readings, which I very much regretted because the material was so useful, engaging, and good.Despite this, ESA was my favorite class of the semester, and the one to which I devoted the majority of my study not because I wanted to do well in the course, but because I actually wanted to learn what Professor Grubler had to teach. ESA exposed me to more new material and challenged my previously-held ideas more that anything I've encountered since... gosh, maybe in the entire span of my professional career and prior schooling. I really appreciated the material and actually enjoyed being so challenged.

There are very few energy programs in the US, and very few energy classes at FES. This class actually provides a system-level view of the energy, well, the energy system that is lacking just about anywhere else.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Learning so much about the details of energy systems

Getting the systems perspective on energy. I hadn't learned about conventional fuels before, except from the perspective of environmentalists - so this was very important for me. Also getting a general understanding of orders of magnitude for things like energy production, consumption on a world, per country, per-capita basis.
The lectures are very informative and rich in material. Sometimes its hard to take it all in.
You truly gain a deeper understanding of both the theoretical and the technical side of energy systems.
Some of the assigned reading materials, including the Energy Primer, and guest lectures.
Lectures and guest lectures
Learning such a rich range of materials from a remarkable professor.
The problem sets were more than practical and helpful.
Problem sets. Comprehensiveness of the course.
The material in this course was unique and gave me some new perspectives on the global energy system
The material covered in the first five weeks.
Learning the fundamentals of energy conversions, jargon, and arithmetic was helpful. Arnulf is an entertaining and informative, if admittedly biased, lecturer.
Student Learning based on the Problem sets is, in my view one of the strongest learning processes of thecourse.

The course gives a comprehensive overview of energy systems, which is quite valuable for anybody in theenvironmental field. I also appreciate that the course focuses on the "energy demand" perspective rather than energy supply and incorporates concepts from systems theory.

Professor Grubler leads a real lecture. It was great. He presupposed we'd done the reading and gave a deeper dive in class, putting things into context and showing potential applications beyond what was approached in there reading. There was nothing about this course that felt like freshman year of undergrad--this was a class fitting a professional school.Problem sets were highly educational (although extremely frustrating, which I will cover in the answer to Question 15). The material covered in the professional modules was also appreciated and valuable.Overall, this course stood out among other I took this semester in that it treated students as professional students. I appreciated the lack of hand-holding more than I would have expected.
Focus on demand-side approaches and understanding that demand drives supply rather than always focusing on the supply-side of the energy system.
Problem sets, but they need serious revision and improvement.

It was incredibly comprehensive in scope and very thoroughly taught. It completely changed the way I thought about energy and climate change, and it should be required for almost every environmentalist who's interested in climate change, in my opinion. It was very rigorous and challenging, and I learned more from this class than any other this past semester.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Problem sets - the questions were often poorly-written and confusing, leading to quite a bit of wasted time trying to figure out what they were asking. I spent too much time on each problem set in relation to the learning I got in return.

Professional modules: good opportunity to learn more. But how necessary is every section of these? I think there is a lot of opportunity to trim the fat. The hour spent on how to use excel was much more elementary than described in class, and I think a lot of us wished we had skipped that. The section on financial modeling in the last PM was duplicative and not necessary. TY's presentation on discount rates was not really relevant, especially that early on, and because his discount rate formula was not even the one we needed to use when discount rates finally did come into the picture for PS5.Also - I think Prof. Grubler can go a long way in making students feel more comfortable answering his questions and asking their own. Being made to feel stupid if you answer wrong quickly created a situation where no one wanted to answer his questions, even the most simple ones. I appreciate his sense of humor, and I think most of us understood that he didn't seriously think we were dumb for answering incorrectly.But no one wants to be embarrassed. And the fear of embarrassment, I think, has a particularly strong effect on women, who were much less vocal in this class than in others I took, and much less vocal than their proportion of the class would suggest. In a field that is already male-dominated, a little more consideration for how to encourage women's participation would be much appreciated.
See question 13.
The instructions on the problem sets could be a bit clearer
The problem sets can be very vaguely worded at times

1) Problem set instructions should be improved for clarity. TA's should answer questions about the problem set instructions in a straight forward manner.2) Required readings should be talked about in class.3) The professor should avoid making crude jokes - they are a distraction / irrelevant to the material discussed.4) Exam grades should not be posted publicly with the accompanying students' name.5) Mid-term exams should be returned, with comments, to the student. Exams can only be viewed in the registrar's office and a solution key is not left with the registrar. Furthermore, comments were not provided on the exam.6) For the final, approximately 1/3 of the material came from a single lecture. We were told to study materials for the final which did not correspond to the materials that would have helped us succeed on the final.
Change the testing and let student's review their midterm.

Gil DePaula was especially incompetent as a TA.Grubler should realize grades may be important to some students for different reasons (funding stipulations, future PhD applications). That doesn't mean he shouldn't grade harshly, but he should be receptive when a student wants to legitimately contest the way something was graded (e.g. something counted wrong that is actually right). It just makes people feel they are treated fairly, as opposed to a blanket curve on all grades.
Maybe the problem sets should be addressed in a way that TAs can actually help in working on the problem sets and provide not only guidance and the solutions.
Time commitment could be decreased.

I felt like much of the material that was covered was not clearly explained. I donât think the professor tries very hard to ensure his students understand thematerial. Either we get it or we donât.

Lecture is a little tangential at time, it could become a little more focused.Also, it would be useful to drill the course material that will be tested on. Many times problems were thrown at us on the midterm with it being only briefly or tangentially covered, which is slightly annoying.

The readings for the course seemed to be front-loaded in the semester, leaving not much reading for the latter half. I would suggest that if the professor wants students to do all the reading, he should spread out the reading more evenly throughout the semester so it's more feasible to actually complete the reading on time.

The course could benefit from more coherent organization, especially during the second half of the course. It felt like during the second half of the course we breezed through topics rather than going into sufficient depth to understand them. Greater depth on energy models, and energy production technologies would have been useful.

The class was capped to 50 students, based on the space restrictions of Sage 24, when there are bigger rooms available.During the lectures, there are several highly conceptual explanations, that might need an easier way to translate concepts, specially considering a non-technical class background
While the lectures were very good, I think the class would be more engaging if there were more student-led discussion in addition to a conventional lecture-based class.

The problem set instructions could be made much clearer. If this sounds nitpicky, it is: to have this be the biggest weakness of a class is the marking of a strong course. However, this is not insignificant. There were several times when--even working in large groups--questions were completely misinterpreted because of unclear wording, which meant that we didn't get to complete the assignment as it was intended. Overall, I found the assignments to be well thought out and [mostly]useful, so when we couldn't complete something as intended because we couldn't understand it, it felt like a missed opportunity. I'd suggest vetting of the question wording in advance of problem set release.The exception to usefulness alluded to above is the amount of legwork necessary to complete problem sets. While I don't mind a heavy workload at all, I think more problem sets could include givens while maintaining the educational capacity. Three quarters of my time spent not his course was Googling--that's time that came at the cost of reading for the course. It was essential to complete the problem sets, so there was no way around it, yet it still felt like a tragic misuse of time that could have been spent reading the urban chapter of the Global Energy Analysis. I understand that this was to impart the difficulty of finding reputable sources, but I feel that decreasing the amount of legwork by 25% (by including more givens) would still impart the same lesson while giving time to complete readings also.A suggestion: list the evening modules on Classes V2 and/or in the course catalog. Many students were unaware that this course entailed class sessions beyond those in the course catalog (only the Monday afternoon sessions were listed) and so we scheduled other classes for Wednesday nights. Because professional modules on Wednesdays contained vital information (both for our learning and for the exams) these really could not be skipped. That led to a number of us being forced to skip our other regular Wednesday classes to attend the professional modules. Had this conflict been known during shopping period, we could have planned accordingly.And one complaint, if I may: the midterm exam tested deprecation/interest calculations. This materialhad not been covered prior to the exam: it's first appearance was there. Following the midterm, we covered the topic in a professional module and discussed it in class (and I did independent research online to further learn it). It felt inappropriate to test on a topic prior to its introduction into course material.
I think the TAs could be more effective if they actually had office hours or discussion sessions for reading material.

Problem sets were often ambiguous and poorly explained. TFs did little to alleviate any problems students had, we were really on our own. Professor has an interesting opinion of FES students and seems quite biased against them as he makes clear in his lectures and grading notes.

The wording of problem set questions need to be dramatically improved. They were very unclear most of the time, and some of the TAs offered little to no help whatsoever. There was a real disconnect from the lecture material and the problem sets in terms of instruction on how to complete the quantitative assignments, and I would have been completely lost without the aid of a group for each problem set.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: There was no direct relationship between homework assignments and lectures. It could be improved by beinglinked.
The class program should be more in relation with the problem, some more guidance on the problem sets should be provided
The relationship between the lectures and the discussions could be improved if the classroom environment were a little less harsh. That way, more students would participate in discussions.

There are several (mostly student driven) Profesional modules, which are not necesarily directly related to the class. However, they cover concepts that might be of interest and/or may be applicable to the Problem Sets.Higher level of debate will be beneficial for this sessions.

The optional professional skills modules overall were helpful. I especially appreciated the opportunity for extra credit and the requirement to "iterate" with Arnulf. I enjoyed seeing classmates present on different topics.

N/A - The class was lecture, complimented by professional modules. Linkages were obvious and natural. Professional modules were essentially additional lecture sessions, albeit with delegated authority. They were useful and informative.Substantial group work occurred outside of class as we collaborated on problem sets -- this was probably my favorite aspect of the course. Professor Grubler understands group work: don't assign it, just stand back and let it happen. Grade independently at the end. This is head-and-shoulders above the prescribed approaches of other courses with regard to efficacy.

Professional modules were occasionally useful (half the time?) but often got too deep into things that we had little initial familiarity with. Ultimately they seemed like a waste of time for anyone not going directly into the energy field.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Essential course for anyone interested in energy, climate and carbon.
Key class in Energy curricula
This course fits into my overall program in the way that my interest is energy and environment.
This course is a prerequisite for many other courses that I plan to take at FES as part of the energy and environment specialization
This is a core starting class for my energy interests.
I am interested in renewable energy and energy efficiency. An introductory course on energy systems is therefore very useful to me.
The course covers Energy Sytems in a quite holistic way, using hard sciences and facts as milestones, but trigger the many social needs of Energy Management, which are essencial in my home country
This course was great in terms of pulling together all the "random" things I had learned about energy into a coherent and more complete understanding of energy systems globally.

This is the foundational bedrock of all that I am interested in, and the course of my future study and career. I am interested in energy policy and technology, and ESA is The Overview Course. I would suggest that it be added to the five foundations classes listed by the school because it is so fundamental to understanding the energy, climate, natural resource, and human health challenge faced by our generation. This class made me glad I walked away from a scholarship at Duke to attend FES without financial aid.

Energy is a key part of what I did before FES and what I'll do after FES, and having a system-level understanding is critical to being effective in the energy world, potentially more effective than many people already immersed in the current energy world are capable of being without that system-level understanding.
Industrial ecology uses systems analysis and requires some knowledge about energy systems as well.

This class should be mandatory for anyone who's pursuing energy at FES. It is the perfect primer for diving further into the discipline, and really anyone who wants to talk intelligently about climate change should take this class.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to learn about energy systems so I can understand them in more detail
Energy touches everything - our climate, our mountains, our rivers, our oceans. This course grounds the severity and complexity of the overall energy problematique.
Program specific
to get a deeper understanding of energy issues and how they relate to the environment
This course is a prerequisite for many other courses that I plan to take at FES as part of the energy and environment specialization
See above.
I wanted to learn about how energy systems function, especially in urban contexts.
To gain a better understanding of the interaction of energy supply and demand at a global scale.
ESA was somehow a refresher of many physcial/thermodynamics concepts, and also a link of the aplicaction of those hard sciences to social and environmental problem solving
It has a great reputation at FES. I knew it would be challenging, which is what I was hoping for.

I needed answers to why renewables weren't already dominating our policy conversations and investment decisions, and wow, did ESA give that. Simply understanding suppy and demand densities (a small portion of this course) completely illuminated a heretofore unknown aspect of this puzzle to me.As a result of ESA, I am much more prepared to have a positive impact on our transition toward less carbon-intense fuels. I didn't know what I didn't know before, and now I have a much better sense of what I don't know, which is incredibly valuable.
Necessary for my intended career and work, and an excellent professor.
I hoped to build systems analysis skills and a basic foundational knowledge about energy.

I wanted to learn more about how how energy conversion technologies and overall systems work in addition to the state of renewable energy technologies. This is a prerequisite for nearly every other energy course at FES, so this was the class I was most excited about taking this semester.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Pretty much
YES
Yes. Many topics are covered, but you can sink your teeth into the issues you really care about.

Somewhat. I had hoped to go over the pros and cons of different strategies of meeting energy demand, including the pros and cons of different environmental technologies. I did not expect the course to be quite as theoretical as it was.
Yes
Yes.
the knowledge meets my expectations, I have learnt a lot from this course
Yes.
I did gain some knowledge, but the class wasn't what I expected and, to be honest, I don't think I can even clearly summarize what I actually learned from it.
Yes, it is a wholly worthwhile class to take. I learned quite a bit.
Yes, except I would've liked to see more attention paid to urban systems.
In some respects. The basic conversions and calculations were useful to learn. However, I expected to learn more about the primary energy supply technologies, and energy modeling techniques.
Yes - Further work with Modeling might have been usefull
Yes.

Exceeded. Far exceeded.It was painful, completing all those problem sets along the way, but the course far exceeded my expectations for exposure to new ideas and information. The best class I've taken at FES thus far.
Skills and knowledge exceeded my expectations and the resources provided are phenomenal.
I felt that I learned considerably less than I thought I would.

Yes, although I thought the class would spend more time talking about how particular energy conversion technologies actually worked, i.e. the engineering behind solar PVs etc. However, the class was much broader than that, and it became a lot more economically focused than I would have preferred.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Great comradery factor working together on the problem sets.

Students organized themselves into groups to study and make sense of the problem set assignments. The instructions to the problem sets were typically difficult to make sense of. Although the professor at the beginning of class elected two students to go over the problem sets to make sure they were clear, the professor allegedly did not make any of their numerous recommended changes. While some difficulty in deciphering the problem sets is acceptable, many of the problem sets were unnecessarily confusing, unclear, and at times contained false notes/instructions (due potentially to reorganizing of the problem sets over time, resulting, for example in instructions to one problem being listed under another, etc.). To summarize, the difficulty of understanding the problem set instructions did not contribute to my understanding / learning of the process of answering the questions asked.
This was informally set up among groups. It was helpful for me.
One of the best part of the class, really helpful
Used group work to get through problem sets. It was very helpful for talking through and overcoming challenging problems.

Group work for the class is not required, but recommended. Most of the problem set solving were done in a relatively stable group, which also served as study group for the examans.Group work is nearly a must, to discuss concepts and problem solving mechanisms, in order to be successful in the class

It is helpful to work on homework assignments with other students because each person has their own way of solvingproblems and thinking about the assignment. It's an opportunity for everyone to learn and to teach each other.

All group work was informal: Professor Grubler allowed collaborative work on problem sets, with individual grading at the conclusion. This was ideal for a professional school, as it allowed students to select those with whim we wanted to work and when we wanted to do the work, without making anyone's score beholden to another person's work ethic (or lack thereof). I very much appreciated that it was not prescribed.If Yale and FES are about making connections that will serve us in our careers beyond graduate school, then ESA is the course that people should take. The bonding that occurred at problem set work sessions is worth the tuition. There has not been another experience--not SIGs, not TGIF, not even MODs--that can compare. During ESA I got to know the colleagues I will consult for the rest of my career, and the group experience of the course is not to be missed.

The problem sets would have been nearly impossible for me without the collective brainpower of groups. The disadvantage, however, were the logistical constraints that group work imposes, and I had to plan most of my other schoolwork around when everyone could meet to work on the problem sets.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Prepare to spend a lot of time on the problem sets
Don't worry to much about any one assignment. Don't work alone if you plan to do well. Pay attention to detail.
Ask as many questions as you can in class. The professor is a wealth of knowledge on many energy and climate sub-topics.
Start the problem sets early and email your TAs with questions!

I donot recommend this course. I found the professor difficult to follow. The professor did not introduce topics well so that often times students were lost. His personality is authoritative, which is not inviting to classroom discussion. Also, his accompanying slides, contained little information. This means that if a student became lost, it would be difficult to get "back on track" by looking at the notes on the slides.
Take this course.
Work hard. Don't be intimidated.
strongly recommend, also recommend to be ready for hard work
Take really, really good notes during class.
Pay very careful attention to everything the professor says in class
The same as everyone else: work hard and don't save any of the assignments to the last minute. Also, if he says the midterm is just on the primer, it's a lie. It'll cover everything.
Read the primer and know it. Don't get down about grades, and enjoy it while you can!

If your focus is on energy, this remains a very useful course. Give yourself time for the problem sets. And try to push Arnulf to teach more concrete material and spend a little less time delving into his own (very strong) opinions.
Review application criteria and apply in advance.Request a clear indication of who are selected as Â¨Proof readersÂ¨ and make sure they do at least a decent task.Work in groups for Problem Sets
Take it!

Apply. Don't even question yourself. Apply.Know that ESA will be your semester. Set the expectation early that you will not be able to complete all the work for your other classes because ESA will rule your time. Know that and do it anyway, because it IS what you came here for. This Is The Class. Apply.
If you have any interest in energy work at all, you need to take this class. TAKE IT. PERIOD.
Don't.

Prepare to make this class your number one priority, and you will have to sacrifice some other class' schoolwork to complete the problem sets. Work on them well, well ahead of time, and know the primer inside and out.
